title: 113_s1385
content: The Act titled "Federal Judgeship Act of 2013" may be cited as such. It includes provisions for circuit judges for the circuit courts of appeals. The "Federal Judgeship Act of 2013" authorizes the appointment of additional circuit judges for the ninth and sixth circuit courts of appeals, including temporary judgeships for the ninth circuit. The Act aims to address judicial vacancies and maintain the balance of judges in the respective circuits. Title 28, United States Code will be updated to reflect the changes in the number of permanent circuit judgeships authorized by the Federal Judgeship Act of 2013 for each judicial circuit. The number of circuit judges for each judicial circuit ranges from 6 to 33, as authorized by the Federal Judgeship Act of 2013. The number of circuit judges for each judicial circuit ranges from 6 to 33, as authorized by the Federal Judgeship Act of 2013. Tenth and Eleventh circuits have 12 judges each. SEC. 3. DISTRICT JUDGES FOR THE DISTRICT COURTS. The President shall appoint additional district judges for various districts, including Delaware, California, Texas, Arizona, Colorado, and Washington. The President shall appoint additional district judges for various districts, including Indiana, Florida, New York, Wisconsin, California, and New Jersey. The President shall appoint additional district judges for various districts, including Indiana, Florida, New York, Wisconsin, California, and New Jersey. Additionally, there will be 2 additional district judges for the southern district of Texas, 1 for the district of Minnesota, 1 for the northern district of Georgia, 1 for the district of Nevada, 1 for the district of New Mexico, and 1 for the southern district of New York. Temporary judgeships include 1 for the eastern district of California, 1 for the western district of Texas, and 4 for the district of Arizona. The President appoints additional district judges for various districts, including Arizona, California, Florida, New Jersey, Minnesota, Missouri, and Georgia. The President appoints additional district judges for districts in Nevada, Oregon, New York, Tennessee, and Virginia. Vacancies in these offices occur 10 years after confirmation. The first vacancies in the office of district judge in Arizona and the central district of California occurring 10 years after the confirmation of temporary judges shall not be filled. Existing judgeships in various districts authorized by previous Acts shall now be authorized under section 133 of title 28, United States Code, with the incumbents holding office under the amended section. The table in section 133 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to reflect changes in the total number of permanent district judgeships authorized. The table in section 133 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to reflect changes in the total number of permanent district judgeships authorized. The number of District Judges in various states are as follows: Alabama - Northern: 8, Middle: 3, Southern: 3; Alaska: 3; Arizona: 19; Arkansas - Eastern: 5, Western: 3; California - Northern: 19, Eastern: 12, Central: 38, Southern: 16. The number of District Judges in various states are as follows: Southern Colorado - 16, Connecticut - 8, Delaware - 5, District of Columbia - 15, Florida: Northern - 5, Middle - 20, Southern - 21, Georgia: Northern - 12, Middle - 4, Southern - 3, Hawaii - 3, Idaho - 3. In Illinois, there are 22 District Judges in the Northern region, 4 in the Central region, and 4 in the Southern region. In Indiana, there are 5 District Judges in the Northern region and 6 in the Southern region. Iowa has 2 District Judges in the Northern region and 3 in the Southern region. Kansas has 6 District Judges. Kentucky has 5 District Judges in the Eastern region, 4 in the Western region, and 1 in both the Eastern and Western regions. Louisiana has 12 District Judges in the Eastern region. Louisiana has 12 District Judges in the Eastern region, 3 in the Middle region, and 7 in the Western region. Maine has 3 District Judges. Maryland has 10 District Judges. Massachusetts has 13 District Judges. Michigan has 15 District Judges in the Eastern region and 4 in the Western region. Minnesota has 8 District Judges. Mississippi has 3 District Judges in the Northern region and 6 in the Southern region. Missouri has 7 District Judges in the Eastern region and 5 in the Western region. New York has different numbers of District Judges in its Northern, Southern, Eastern, and Western regions. North Carolina also has District Judges in its Eastern region. North Carolina has 3 regions with 4 District Judges each. North Dakota has 2 District Judges. Ohio has 2 regions with 11 and 8 District Judges. Oklahoma has 4 regions with varying numbers of District Judges. Oregon has 6 District Judges. Pennsylvania has 2 regions with 22 and 6 District Judges. Puerto Rico has 7 District Judges. Rhode Island has 3 District Judges. South Carolina has 10 District Judges. South Dakota has 3 District Judges. Tennessee has 3 regions with 5, 4, and 5 District Judges respectively. Texas has 4 regions with 12, 21, 10, and 17 District Judges respectively. In the western region, Utah has 5 judges, Vermont has 2 judges, Virginia has 11 judges in the eastern region and 4 judges in the western region, Washington has 4 judges in the eastern region and 9 judges in the western region, West Virginia has 3 judges in the northern region and 5 judges in the southern region, Wisconsin has 5 judges in the eastern region and 3 judges in the western region, and Wyoming has 3 judges. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: Sums are authorized for this Act, including funds for judicial positions.
